US

  • US Business Inventories MM Jan 0.8% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%, Rev. 0.8%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Casino stocks Wynn (WYNN), Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts (MGM) and Melco Resorts (MLCO) surged on Monday, with the move being attributed to Macau casino revenue printing the highest figure this year, coming in at the top end of estimates, despite being a 0.4% decrease form March 2018. FedEx (FDX) outperformed after constructive comments from Credit Suisse; however Berenberg downgraded FedEx, but upgraded competitor UPS (UPS) which also surged. Strong Chinese and US manufacturing data spiked risk appetite causing high beta stocks such as the chipmakers, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Micron Technology (MU), Intel (INTC), and Qualcomm (QCOM) to all trade higher, in addition to US listed Chinese stocks such as JD.com (JD) and Baidu (BIDU), and trade sensitive stocks such as Caterpillar (CAT) and Boeing (BA). United Technologies (UTX) traded near the top of the DJIA thanks to PT rise at Jefferies. Morgan Stanley initiated big oil coverage, where it preferred Chevron (CVX) over Exxon Mobil (XOM). Wedbush added Activision Blizzard (ATVI) to its Best Ideas list, seeing the stock surge on the open. Celgene (CELG) lagged behind competitors after UBS downgraded the Bristol-Myers (BMY) target to Neutral from Buy, citing the stocks recent strong performance as the merger deal becomes more likely, following independent merger review approval and investor Starboard Value withdrawing its opposition to the deal. Lyft (LYFT) saw double digit losses following its IPO, a Neutral initiation at Guggenheim didn’t help, and threw some cold water on hopes of an IPO mania revival, with heavyweights Uber, WeWork and Airbnb all likely to be more cautious about coming to market. SPX +1.16% at 1867, NDX +1.35% at 7478, DJI +1.27% at 26258.

Risk-on was the theme after China PMI data reassured that the country has seen a stabilisation in the manufacturing sector, and combined with a chipper ISM manufacturing report out of the US, the stage was set for yields to rise. In fact, it appears yields are set for the biggest-single day rise in around three-months (2s yields +5.3bps at settle, 5s yields +6.9bps, 10s yields +8.2bps, 30s yields +7bps). Major curves bear-steepened modestly (1.2bps to 2.6bps), though 10s30s saw some small narrowing. The much-watched 3m/10yr spread moved back into positive territory with reassuring global growth signs (ex-EZ PMIs); while this spread is only a symptom of a much larger cause, analysts seem to be more generally buying-into the argument presented by some Fed officials of late, which suggested that structural factors have diminished the recession signal, though the growth concerns remain valid. US T-note futures (M9) settled 19+ ticks lower at 123-19+.

UK Parliament rejects all 4 Brexit options in indicative votes
content:
Results

(273 For vs. 276 Against) Motion (C) on CUSTOMS UNION (Table by Ken Clarke [Con] and Hilary Benn [Lab]) – Withdrawal Agreement has to have a permanent and comprehensive UK-wide customs union, i.e. a “soft Brexit”.

(261 For vs. 282 Against) Motion (D) COMMONS MARKET 2.0 (Tabled by Nick Boles [Con] and Lucy Powell [Lab]) – UK would re-join the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) and European Economic Area (EEA), meaning the UK will remain the in single market

(280 For vs. 292 Against) Motion (E) CONFIRMATORY PUBLIC VOTE (Tabled by Peter Kyle [Lab]) – Any deal cannot be ratified in parliament without public consent, i.e. people’s vote.

(191 For vs. 292 Against) Motion (G) - PARLIAMENTARY SUPREMACY (Tabled by Joanna Cherry [SNP]) – UK would seek a further extension if a deal is not agreed by 10th April. If the EU does not accept an extension, MPs would be asked to vote between a no-deal Brexit or revoking Article 50. If MPs vote in favour of the revocation, the future relationship between the UK and the EU will be discussed.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 1 April 2019: Risk on as manufacturing data bounces higher
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

US MARKET WRAP 1 April 2019: Risk on as manufacturing data bounces higher

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar flat, treasuries down, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: US ISM Mfg stronger in March; weak US retail sales point to slowing growth; ECB’s De Guindos on potential bank compensation for negative rates;

* AHEAD: Australian Building Approvals; UK Construction PMI; US Durable Goods; RBA Rate Decision; ECB's Praet; Fed's Kaplan; Supply from Japan & UK

 

* US ISM: The US ISM Manufacturing Index for March rose by 1.1 points from 54.2 to 55.3, a firm beat on the expected 54.5. “Although the US economy reached an inflection point in Q4 and momentum is now slowing, manufacturing activity has kept resilient in the face of multiple crosscurrents,” analysts at Oxford Economics note. Breaking down the index, the employment index was the biggest tailwind for the headline figure, printing a multi-year record increase of 5.2 points to 57.5 (NFP on Friday), following the disappointing February figure. Elsewhere, the new orders index and production index showed healthy increases by 1.9 points and 1 point respectively, bringing the new orders index “right in line with the Q4 average, highlighting that demand remains quite strong,” the consultancy highlights. However, “stronger new orders and production were mostly offset by slower supplier deliveries and less inventory-building,” where the supplier deliveries index printed 54.2, the lowest reading since January 2017, and the inventories index falling from 53.4 to 51.8. After decreasing in the prior two months, the input prices figure showed some stabilisation with a rise to 54.3, “Overall, inflation remains benign and with the Fed’s dovish paradigm shift, we foresee no further rate hikes as the FOMC has likely reached the terminal rate for this cycle.”

* US RETAIL SALES: February retail sales showed a surprise contraction, where the M/M change printed -0.2%, missing the expected 0.3% rise and paring back January’s 0.2% rise, dampening some of Monday’s strong risk appetite, although January was revised higher to +0.7%. Capital Economics’ analysts comment, “The decline in the headline figure came despite a 0.7% M/M rise in spending on motor vehicles, although that in itself is a little hard to square with the recent weakness of the manufacturers’ unit sales figures.” Elsewhere beneath the headline, gas station sales rose by 1%, but dragging the index was the 4.4% fall in building material sales, “although that simply reversed an identical rise in January.” Capital Economics highlights that excluding the volatile components, which were likely to be impacted by weather shocks, the control group fell by 0.2%, well beneath the expected 0.4% rise. “Even allowing for a decent rebound in underlying sales in March, we estimate that real consumption growth slowed to no more than 1.0% in Q1, from 2.5% in Q4.” The consultancy concludes by forecasting that this weaker consumption will reinforce the Fed’s patient stance, and they, “expect the Fed’s next move will be to cut interest rates.”

* EUROZONE CPI: Eurozone inflation slipped in March to 1.4% (prev. 1.5%); the core measure declined by more than expected at 0.8% (cons 0.9% vs prev 1.0%). While much of this drop in the core will reverse next month, the underlying picture continues to show modest price growth, ING said, noting that the timing of Easter will continue to distort inflation through the spring months. "Not too much to get excited about, but the overall picture of bleak core inflation remains," ING writes, "next month will likely see some overshooting of 1% due to the Easter effect reversing, but the underlying story remains one of subdued core inflation as businesses continue to take higher wage growth in their margins because of global uncertainty."

* ECB: ECB's Draghi (Dovish) said on Monday that substantial monetary policy stimulus remains essential, in light of uncertainties regarding geopolitical factors. ECB's De Guindos (Neutral) said that negative rates are quite important for economic activity, adding that the low profitability of banks goes beyond potential impact of low rates. De Guindos also said he was analysing whether banks need compensation for negative rates, although it had not been discussed by policy makers.

* BOC POLOZ: BOC Gov Poloz says outlook still warrants an interest rate below the neutral range; data consistent with expectation that below-potential growth will be transitory.

* PREVIEW: RBA RATE ANNOUNCEMENT DUE TUESDAY 2ND APRIL AT 0430BST/2230CDT/1130HKT. The implied yield curve suggests the next move in rates will be lower with a 25bps cut in July and again in December this year. Click here for the full preview.

* BREXIT: Indicative votes on Brexit options will begin at 2000 BST, with results expected to be announced around 2200 BST. The Speaker has selected the following motions to be voted on: (C) CUSTOMS UNION (Table by Ken Clarke [Con] and Hilary Benn [Lab]) – Withdrawal Agreement has to have a permanent and comprehensive UK-wide customs union, i.e. a “soft Brexit” (this option garnered the most support of previous indicative votes, with lawmakers voting 272 nay vs 264 aye); (D) COMMONS MARKET 2.0 (Tabled by Nick Boles [Con] and Lucy Powell [Lab]) – UK would re-join the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) and European Economic Area (EEA), meaning the UK will remain the in single market (this was widely rejected on 27th March, 283 against vs 180 for). (E) CONFIRMATORY PUBLIC VOTE (Tabled by Peter Kyle [Lab]) – Any deal cannot be ratified in parliament without public consent, i.e. people’s vote (motion previously received 268 for and 295 against). (G) PARLIAMENTARY SUPREMACY (Tabled by Joanna Cherry [SNP]) – UK would seek a further extension if a deal is not agreed by 10th April. If the EU does not accept an extension, MPs would be asked to vote between a no-deal Brexit or revoking Article 50. If MPs vote in favour of the revocation, the future relationship between the UK and the EU will be discussed (MPs have not voted on this motion before). The latest seems to suggest that opposition Labour have whipped their lawmakers to vote for motion D; the Tories' Cabinet minister will once again abstain, while the rest of the Conservative MPs will be allowed a free vote.

* WTI (K9) SETTLED USD 1.45 HIGHER AT USD 61.59/BBL; BRENT (M9) SETTLED USD 1.43 HIGHER AT USD 69.01/BBL. Oil prices began the week on the front foot, finding support from strong manufacturing PMI data out of China and manufacturing ISM in the US, as well as further output cuts becoming evident from OPEC+. However, the Eurozone gauge came in weaker, and below the 50 level. March OPEC surveys have begun hitting; Reuters’ poll sees oil output falling 280k BPD M/M, to 30.4mln BPD (the lowest since 2015); members subject to the supply-cut deal are seen to achieve 135% compliance, compared to 101% in the prior month, with Saudi and Venezuela posting the largest production declines, which isn’t too surprising given that Saudi is spearheading the cuts and Venezuela’s inability to produce gives it little choice. Elsewhere, the Iranian Oil Minister said it should be easy to extend the OPEC+ supply cut deal; the Russian Central Bank says it does not rule out an extension of OPEC+ output agreements into H2 2019; Iraqi crude oil exports reached 3.377mln BPD in March vs. 3.62mln in February, with oil exports from southern ports at 3.254mln bpd, according to the Oil Ministry, which contradicts the 3.45mln figure given last week by Iraqi officials.

* SPX +1.16% at 1867, NDX +1.35% at 7478, DJI +1.27% at 26258. SECTORS: Energy +1.37%, Materials +1.50%, Industrials +2.07%, Cons Discretionary +1.17%, Cons Staples -0.21%, Healthcare +0.17%, Financials +2.42%, Tech +1.40%, Telecoms +1.45%, Utilities -0.71%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Casino stocks Wynn (WYNN), Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts (MGM) and Melco Resorts (MLCO) surged on Monday, with the move being attributed to Macau casino revenue printing the highest figure this year, coming in at the top end of estimates, despite being a 0.4% decrease form March 2018. FedEx (FDX) outperformed after constructive comments from Credit Suisse; however Berenberg downgraded FedEx, but upgraded competitor UPS (UPS) which also surged. Strong Chinese and US manufacturing data spiked risk appetite causing high beta stocks such as the chipmakers, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Micron Technology (MU), Intel (INTC), and Qualcomm (QCOM) to all trade higher, in addition to US listed Chinese stocks such as JD.com (JD) and Baidu (BIDU), and trade sensitive stocks such as Caterpillar (CAT) and Boeing (BA). United Technologies (UTX) traded near the top of the DJIA thanks to PT rise at Jefferies. Morgan Stanley initiated big oil coverage, where it preferred Chevron (CVX) over Exxon Mobil (XOM). Wedbush added Activision Blizzard (ATVI) to its Best Ideas list, seeing the stock surge on the open. Celgene (CELG) lagged behind competitors after UBS downgraded the Bristol-Myers (BMY) target to Neutral from Buy, citing the stocks recent strong performance as the merger deal becomes more likely, following independent merger review approval and investor Starboard Value withdrawing its opposition to the deal. Lyft (LYFT) saw double digit losses following its IPO, a Neutral initiation at Guggenheim didn’t help, and threw some cold water on hopes of an IPO mania revival, with heavyweights Uber, WeWork and Airbnb all likely to be more cautious about coming to market.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 19+ TICKS LOWER AT 123-19+. Risk-on was the theme after China PMI data reassured that the country has seen a stabilisation in the manufacturing sector, and combined with a chipper ISM manufacturing report out of the US, the stage was set for yields to rise. In fact, it appears yields are set for the biggest-single day rise in around three-months (2s yields +5.3bps at settle, 5s yields +6.9bps, 10s yields +8.2bps, 30s yields +7bps). Major curves bear-steepened modestly (1.2bps to 2.6bps), though 10s30s saw some small narrowing. The much-watched 3m/10yr spread moved back into positive territory with reassuring global growth signs (ex-EZ PMIs); while this spread is only a symptom of a much larger cause, analysts seem to be more generally buying-into the argument presented by some Fed officials of late, which suggested that structural factors have diminished the recession signal, though the growth concerns remain valid.

* FX WRAP: A risk-on environment saw USD sellers overnight, after China's official manufacturing PMI surprised to the upside in March, following stabilisation seen in February. The mood was firm enough to ignore the dreadful EZ PMIs. There was a kneejerk lower after US retail sales fell short in Feb, though the Jan data was all revised up; the USD pared back losses in wake of a solid ISM report, which helped dispel some concerns about the growth slowdown (in conjunction with the China data). It helped the activity currencies (AUD, NZD, CAD). The JPY was weaker, underpinned by a weak Tankan report overnight, while the US 3m/10yr curve exited inversion. The TRY managed to recoup sharp losses after Turkey's local elections, while the ZAR caught a bid after Moody's delayed its review on the South Africa's ratings. Elsewhere in EMFX, the MXN held up well despite Trump's recent threats to close the border between Mexico and the US.

* GBP: Sterling also trades stronger, supported by decent manufacturing PMI; however, many have suggested that the bounce is a function of stockpiling and completing workloads ahead of Brexit, with some analysts suggesting that we are unlikely to see the strength sustained in the months ahead, absence any movement on Brexit. Nevertheless, Capital Economics' analysts see upside for the GBP in the month's ahead. Currently, GBP is being split by numerous soft and hard Brexit options, and as these are removed, the path to a softer Brexit could help support the pound, the argument goes. However, amid all the optimism, it is worth reiterating that if Parliament cannot give EU policymakers a convincing game plan for why the Article 50 process should be extended, the default position remains that the UK will leave on 12 April, without a deal; it is worth adding that many are expecting movement before this happens, but we would not that Brexit optimism doesn't have a great track record of showing follow-through.

* ZAR: Moody's delayed its rating review of South Africa on Friday (the consensus was looking for an unchanged Baa3/stable, though some had expected an outlook revision, or an outright downgrade). ZAR traders have reacted positively, seeing USDZAR fall by over 2%. However, this seems like just a delay; RBC argues that the CRA may be waiting for greater clarity that will be seen after May's elections, however, it buys the nation more time to implement changes to maintain its final investment grade rating.

* TRY: Turkish local elections have seen President Erdogan's AKP party lost control of capital Ankara, as well as other key large cities (though they are set to contest the outcome). The Lira was weaker against the USD, with analysts suggesting that since there is no General Election until 2023, the focus is on policy direction, and it raises uncertainty around the prospects of structural reforms. However, through the course of the session, the TRY pared losses as offshore swap rates rose again, making it more expensive to short the TRY. ABN AMRO's analysts  say that in light of last week's FX interventions, and the election losses, "Turkey is highly vulnerable to a shift in investor sentiment, and depends on foreign investors to fund its current account deficit, the long-term negative implications from the measures taken last week outweigh any short-term gains," and "the actions of the authorities decreased volatility on the lira in the short-term, but is unlikely to provide support to the lira in the longer run." ABN  says "foreign investors are able to anticipate market volatility, but not erratic action by the authorities that result in the drying up of liquidity in currency and interest rate markets. Moreover, the refusal of Turkey to stop the purchase of the Russian missile defence system S-400 could potentially lead to another stand-off between Turkey and the US." These come amid a backdrop of cooling global growth, and ABN thinks investors will shy away from Turkey going forward, resulting in a weaker lira against the dollar. The bank cuts its forecast for the USDTRY to 6.0 from 5.20.

subject: FX WRAP: Risk-on sets the tone
analysis_details:
* FX WRAP: A risk-on environment saw USD sellers overnight, after China's official manufacturing PMI surprised to the upside in March, following stabilisation seen in February. The mood was firm enough to ignore the dreadful EZ PMIs. There was a kneejerk lower after US retail sales fell short in Feb, though the Jan data was all revised up; the USD pared back losses in wake of a solid ISM report, which helped dispel some concerns about the growth slowdown (in conjunction with the China data). It helped the activity currencies (AUD, NZD, CAD). The JPY was weaker, underpinned by a weak Tankan report overnight, while the US 3m/10yr curve exited inversion. The TRY managed to recoup sharp losses after Turkey's local elections, while the ZAR caught a bid after Moody's delayed its review on the South Africa's ratings. Elsewhere in EMFX, the MXN held up well despite Trump's recent threats to close the border between Mexico and the US.

* GBP: Sterling also trades stronger, supported by decent manufacturing PMI; however, many have suggested that the bounce is a function of stockpiling and completing workloads ahead of Brexit, with some analysts suggesting that we are unlikely to see the strength sustained in the months ahead, absence any movement on Brexit. Nevertheless, Capital Economics' analysts see upside for the GBP in the month's ahead. Currently, GBP is being split by numerous soft and hard Brexit options, and as these are removed, the path to a softer Brexit could help support the pound, the argument goes. However, amid all the optimism, it is worth reiterating that if Parliament cannot give EU policymakers a convincing game plan for why the Article 50 process should be extended, the default position remains that the UK will leave on 12 April, without a deal; it is worth adding that many are expecting movement before this happens, but we would not that Brexit optimism doesn't have a great track record of showing follow-through.

* ZAR: Moody's delayed its rating review of South Africa on Friday (the consensus was looking for an unchanged Baa3/stable, though some had expected an outlook revision, or an outright downgrade). ZAR traders have reacted positively, seeing USDZAR fall by over 2%. However, this seems like just a delay; RBC argues that the CRA may be waiting for greater clarity that will be seen after May's elections, however, it buys the nation more time to implement changes to maintain its final investment grade rating.

* TRY: Turkish local elections have seen President Erdogan's AKP party lost control of capital Ankara, as well as other key large cities (though they are set to contest the outcome). The Lira was weaker against the USD, with analysts suggesting that since there is no General Election until 2023, the focus is on policy direction, and it raises uncertainty around the prospects of structural reforms. However, through the course of the session, the TRY pared losses as offshore swap rates rose again, making it more expensive to short the TRY. ABN AMRO's analysts  say that in light of last week's FX interventions, and the election losses, "Turkey is highly vulnerable to a shift in investor sentiment, and depends on foreign investors to fund its current account deficit, the long-term negative implications from the measures taken last week outweigh any short-term gains," and "the actions of the authorities decreased volatility on the lira in the short-term, but is unlikely to provide support to the lira in the longer run." ABN  says "foreign investors are able to anticipate market volatility, but not erratic action by the authorities that result in the drying up of liquidity in currency and interest rate markets. Moreover, the refusal of Turkey to stop the purchase of the Russian missile defence system S-400 could potentially lead to another stand-off between Turkey and the US." These come amid a backdrop of cooling global growth, and ABN thinks investors will shy away from Turkey going forward, resulting in a weaker lira against the dollar. The bank cuts its forecast for the USDTRY to 6.0 from 5.20.

analysis_details: Oil prices began the week on the front foot, finding support from strong manufacturing PMI data out of China and manufacturing ISM in the US, as well as further output cuts becoming evident from OPEC+. However, the Eurozone gauge came in weaker, and below the 50 level. March OPEC surveys have begun hitting; Reuters’ poll sees oil output falling 280k BPD M/M, to 30.4mln BPD (the lowest since 2015); members subject to the supply-cut deal are seen to achieve 135% compliance, compared to 101% in the prior month, with Saudi and Venezuela posting the largest production declines, which isn’t too surprising given that Saudi is spearheading the cuts and Venezuela’s inability to produce gives it little choice. Elsewhere, the Iranian Oil Minister said it should be easy to extend the OPEC+ supply cut deal; the Russian Central Bank says it does not rule out an extension of OPEC+ output agreements into H2 2019; Iraqi crude oil exports reached 3.377mln BPD in March vs. 3.62mln in February, with oil exports from southern ports at 3.254mln bpd, according to the Oil Ministry, which contradicts the 3.45mln figure given last week by Iraqi officials.

UPDATED: BREXIT ROLLING ANALYSIS AND WHAT'S COMING UP
content:
*MONDAY: In light of Friday’s Withdrawal Agreement defeat (margin 58), 8 options have been tabled for today’s fresh set of indicative votes (see below). It is also worth noting that again, these votes will not be legally binding and would just signal a parliamentary majority (if any).

*TODAY’S SCHEDULE [BST]

  • 1700 - ERG meeting to start
  • 2000 - Paper vote on all options selected by House Speaker
  • 2200 - Results expected
  • N.B. 1. Times are subject to change, counting process took around two hours last time, hence results can be expected any time between 2030BST and 2230BST
  • N.B. 2. A group of Tory MPs including Amber Rudd, David Gauke, Greg Clark, David Mundell are to meet tonight short before the indicative votes

 

*MOTIONS SELECTED BY HOUSE SPEAKER

(C) – CUSTOMS UNION (Table by Ken Clarke [Con] and Hilary Benn [Lab]) – Withdrawal Agreement has to have a permanent and comprehensive UK-wide customs union, i.e. a “soft Brexit”.

  • N.B. 1. This was the most popular option last time, 272 voted against and 264 voted in favour (margin 8)
  • N.B. 2. Up to 26 UK ministers are considering voting for this option; assuming they get a free vote, according to Times' Deputy Political Editor Coates

(D) COMMONS MARKET 2.0 (Tabled by Nick Boles [Con] and Lucy Powell [Lab]) – UK would re-join the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) and European Economic Area (EEA), meaning the UK will remain the in single market

  • N.B. 1. This was widely rejected on 27th March, 283 against, 180 for (margin 103)
  • N.B. 2. SNP Party have confirmed support of this motion if selected, according to BBC's Chief Political Correspondent Campbell
  • N. B. 3. Labour will be whipping for this motion if selected by the House Speaker

(E) – CONFIRMATORY PUBLIC VOTE (Tabled by Peter Kyle [Lab]) – Any deal cannot be ratified in parliament without public consent, i.e. people’s vote.

  • N.B. This motion previously received 268 for and 295 against (margin 27)

(G) - PARLIAMENTARY SUPREMACY (Tabled by Joanna Cherry [SNP]) – UK would seek a further extension if a deal is not agreed by 10th April. If the EU does not accept an extension, MPs would be asked to vote between a no-deal Brexit or revoking Article 50. If MPs vote in favour of the revocation, the future relationship between the UK and the EU will be discussed.

  • N.B. MPs have not voted on this motion before

*VOTING SYSTEM: Cabinet are to abstain, other Tory MPs will be given a free vote. It is not yet clear if the same voting system will be used as the first time, i.e. a yes/no vote. A different method may be used to avoid no majority on the motions:

  • STRAIGHT VOTES: Indicative votes usually take the form of a series of votes where MPs can express their support or disapproval for each individual motion. The method usually used to vote in the HoC
  • PREFERENTIAL VOTING: MPs could also be asked to rank different options in order of preference which can then be counted under an Alternative vote system. If any single option receives a majority of first-preference votes, that option will be chosen.
  • EXHAUSTIVE BALLOT: If no options command majority, then the option with the lowest number of first preference votes would be eliminated. The vote would then reach a second stage (and so on) and those who voted for the eliminated option would be allocated amongst the remaining options

 

* TUESDAY/THURSDAY: Potentially May's next opportunity to present her deal to Parliament for vote again.

  • N.B. A government source has said it is unlikely a meaningful vote will be held on Tuesday

* WEDNESDAY: Lawmakers will lay plans to pass legislation that will mandate PM May to ask the EU for an extension, and bind her to the alternative scenario Parliament has indicative it has a majority for (if a majority emerges).

* FIVE POTENTIAL FUTURE SCENARIOS:

  • (1) Parliament tries to force May's hand by agreeing an alternative Brexit plan: Speaker Bercow expected to choose options that did well at the previous indicative votes (customs union, second referendum). Risks: no majority prevails again; could be pointless if May presents her deal again in the wake, and it that passes.
  • (2) May brings her deal back: Talks continue to convince the dissenting Tories and DUP lawmakers (34 and 10 respectively), although it seems unlikely. However, May is pitting her deal against options which are unpopular to many Tories (A Norway model, or second referendum); but many of her Party would likely prefer a no deal.
  • (3) MPs vote for a second referendum (a confirmatory referendum on any deal agreed by Parliament). This was motion that garnered most support at last week’s indicative votes, though failed to generate a majority. Has opposition support, and still an option to be used as an amendment in future legislation. Limited Conservative support. Could be divisive for the country.
  • (4) No deal. Parliament fails to agree and the default remains the UK will leave the EU on 12 April, despite lawmakers having ruled-out this scenario in multiple votes previously. Unless a credible plan is presented to the EU by 10/Apr, there is a risk that some may be reluctant to accept any extension request, and therefore, an exit could happen by accident.
  • (5) May tries to call an election. This has been hinted before as a warning to back May; opposition has already called for an election. Could lead to the EU granting a longer extension, and the UK participating in EU Parliament elections 23-26 May.

*BANK THOUGHTS: 

  • Goldman Sachs believes that the balance of risks surrounding Brexit outcome is tilted to a softer and longer departure. Chances of a modified version of PM May’s deal at 45% (Prev. 50%). Probability of a “no deal” Brexit maintained at 15% and chance of a “no Brexit” raised to 40% (Prev. 35%)
  • Deutsche Bank says likelihood of a no-deal Brexit (on April 12th) to 25% (Prev. 20%), base case is now a general election. Deutsche Bank targets EUR/GBP at 0.90 due to the increasingly high probability of no-deal Brexit. Bank says 15% chance Parliament will fail to reach consensus on Indicative votes

Daily FX Wrap: risk-on start to new week, April and Q2
content:
GBP

Sterling has extended recovery gains in the run up to more indicative voting in Parliament amidst whipping and posturing behind various motions that were given the thumbs down last time, but could receive more backing after PM May’s WA was rejected for a 3rd time last Friday. Cable inched further above 1.3100 to around 1.3125 before fading and Eur/Gbp retreated from circa 0.8625 to just shy of 0.8560, with the Pound deriving support from significantly stronger than forecast UK manufacturing PMI. However, hopes for a softer Brexit if the Customs Union or Common Market 2 alternative options gather momentum or go head-to-head with May’s deal on Wednesday and win are underpinning the Gbp in the main. Note, the Speaker of the HoC is due to select motions shortly and we have a running Brexit analysis post that is regularly updated on our headline feed.

AUD/NZD

The Aussie and Kiwi have lost a bit of their post-Chinese PMI euphoria, and their place at the summit of the G10 table to the Pound in wake of the aforementioned upbeat UK PMI and going into the latest round of Brexit IVs. Aud/Usd remains comfortably above the 0.7100 handle and the 50 DMA at 0.7119, while Nzd/Usd is holding towards the upper end of a 0.6810-37 range amidst broader Greenback weakness post-US retail sales data vs upbeat manufacturing ISM – more on this below. Looking ahead, the Aud may succumb to some pre-RBA jitters and position

DXY

The Dollar and index have regrouped with the aid of a US manufacturing ISM beat and encouraging sub-components, but remain depressed after another disappointing retail sales report, as the DXY struggles to fully recover within a relatively tight 97.026-281 range.

EUR

The single currency has stalled amidst mostly bleak Eurozone manufacturing PMIs and the post-ISM Greenback bounce, but has so far resisted selling pressure ahead of 1.1200, as another ECB member hints at reluctance or reservations to the idea of tiered deposits. However, the NOK and SEK both maintained gains vs the Eur following faster Norwegian and Swedish manufacturing PMI activity and with the former also fuelled by perky oil prices. 

CAD/CHF/JPY

All ending Monday’s EU session on the back foot and underperforming their major peers, as the Loonie weakened in wake of a worrying Canadian manufacturing PMI to 1.3370 vs around 1.3335 pre-release, and the Franc was undermined by a similar slowdown in the Swiss version and weak retail sales, retreating from 0.9936 to 0.9980. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy consolidated above 111.00 and briefly pierced a Fib at 111.20 on the back of an upturn in risk sentiment and a firmer rebound in US Treasury yields.

EM

A very volatile day for the Try with initial weakness down to 5.7030 seen vs the Usd after weekend Turkish elections appeared to have handed key cities, Istanbul and Ankara to President Erdogan’s main opposition, but then the Lira rebounding towards 5.5200 as the ruling AK Party contested results and launched.

  • CELGENE (CELG) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT UBS
  • Coty (COTY) – JPMorgan has added the co. to its short idea list, citing little fundamental reason for the stock to maintain its current valuation. (Newswires)
  • Kellogg (K) – The packaged foods co. is close to an agreement to sell its Keebler, famous Amos and fruit snacks unit to the private Italian-based Ferrero for a value between USD 1bln-1.5bln.

 

1st April 2019

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL), Tesla (TSLA) – Tesla’s VP of Engineering, Michael Schwekutsch, has joined Apple’s Special Project Group, where its autonomous vehicle unit, Project Titan, is located, Schwekutsch is one of several Tesla engineers to join the group. (Electrek)
  • Boeing (BA) – Tensions have been escalating between US and Ethiopian authorities over the handling of data from Boeing’s 737 MAX Jet crash, where the US are accusing Ethiopia of having an “aloof” attitude and being slow to provide information. Elsewhere, Norway Air’s CEO is to hold talks with the co. over issues related to MAX jets, the airline has eighteen 737 MAX 8 jets and is scheduled to take delivery of more. (WSJ/Newswires)
  • Cisco (CSCO) – The tech co.’s CEO Chuck Robbins has said that those who doubted its subscription-based networking models have been wrong, where 65% of its software revenue has originated from subscriptions, with software and service expected to reach 30% of its total revenue over the next few years. (CRN)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The personal products conglomerate has disagreed with Indian regulators’ interim data on its baby powder products, which determines its baby shampoo contains “harmful ingredients”. (Newswires)
  • Merck (MRK) – The pharma giant’s cancer treatment KEYTRUDA, in combination with chemotherapy, has been approved in China for the treatment of lung cancer, conditional on data from the Phase 3 KEYNOTE-189 trial, which would make it the first anti-PD-1 therapy approved for more than one tumour type in the country. Elsewhere, Merck, alongside AstraZeneca (AZN), have been granted FDA Breakthrough Approval Designation for their rare genetics disease treatment in kids, selumetinib. (Newswires)
  • Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) – As the pharmacy introduces efforts to trial tobacco free stores, it has said it has no intentions to stop selling tobacco products completely, a hopeful sign for Altria Group (MO), British American Tobacco (BTI) and Philip Morris (PM). (WSJ)

S&P500

  • Casino/Resorts (LVS, MGM, WYNN, MLCO) – China’s Macau region reported gross casino-related revenue down by 0.4% in March YY to 25.84bln patacas. (Newswires)
  • Citigroup (C) – The bank’s consumer unit, as according to its annual proxy statement, is set to miss its 2020 financial targets, with its head, Stephen Bird, receiving the lowest score amongst his colleagues for financial performance. (FT)
  • Coty (COTY) – The cosmetics co. has announced the extension of the tender offer for 150mln shares by JAB at a price of USD 11.65 per share. Elsewhere, JPMorgan has added the co. to its short idea list, citing little fundamental reason for the stock to maintain its current valuation. (Newswires)
  • Discovery (DISCA) – The broadcaster has signed a “multi-million pound” partnership with the BBC, where Discovery will act as the global home for BBC’s factual series content, including the popular Planet Earth, Blue Planet and Life collection of titles, and provide bespoke development for BBC studios. The deal will see the breakup of broadcaster UKTV and create a new global on-demand video streaming service. (Newswires)
  • Kellogg (K) – The packaged foods co. is close to an agreement to sell its Keebler, famous Amos and fruit snacks unit to the private Italian-based Ferrero for a value between USD 1bln-1.5bln. (CNBC)
  • MasterCard (MA) – The credit card provider has had its price target raised to USD 267 from USD 221 at Deutsche Bank, with analyst Bryan Keane reiterating his Buy rating, citing “strong fundamentals” globally. (Newswires)
  • Southwest (LUV) – The airline has extended its grounding of Boeing’s (BA) 737 MAX jet from April 20th until and through May. Elsewhere, Southwest experienced some technical difficulties which cause delays to flights but has since been resolved. (Newswires)
  • V.F. Corp. (VFC) – The apparel retailer has filed its Form 10 registration statement for its previously announced separation of its Jeanswear unit into a separately traded public company, which will be named Kontoor Brands, containing the Wrangler, Lee and Rock & Republic brands, and the VF Outlet business. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s magazine gave positive mentions for AT&T (T), DowDuPont (DWDP), Dow Inc. (DOW), Amphenol (APH), AbbVie (ABBV), International Paper (IP), Prudential Financial (PRU), Broadcom (AVGO), and Best Buy (BBY). However, the publication was cautious on Apple (AAPL), citing its disappointing Special Event last Monday. (Barron’s)

NASDAQ

  • Activision Blizzard (ATVI) – The video-game developer has been added to Wedbush’s Best Ideas list, analyst Michael Pachter maintains his Outperform rating and USD 56 price target, citing potential for earnings beats for FY19. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The retail giant’s security chief for CEO Jeff Bezos has said that the Saudi government gained access to Bezos’ phone, after an investigation into the leaked text messages of Bezos’ affair in the National Enquirer publication, it is not yet known if the Saudi’s extracted the text messages. Elsewhere, the co. has had its price target raised to USD 2,085 from USD 1,975 at Oppenheimer, after analyst Jason Helfstein reassessed his AWS model. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media co.’s CEO Mark Zuckerberg has called for governments to ramp up their role for regulating the internet in four main areas: to protect society from harmful content; to ensure election integrity; to protect people’s privacy; and to ensure data portability. Elsewhere, BI reports that the co.s has accidentally deleted some old Facebook posts by Zuckerberg such as its historic Instagram acquisition, citing technical errors. (CNBC/BI)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – Researchers have determined that mass user data can be extracted from Tesla vehicles after a crash, where someone with the right aptitude can gain from vehicles sent to salvage. (CNBC)

OTHER NEWS

  • Cable ONE (CABO) – The telecoms co. is to acquire the private Fidelity Communications Co.’s data, voice and video assets for USD 526mln in cash. (Newswires)
  • Cloudera (CLDR) – After attending a data conference, BTIG analyst Edward Parker maintained his Buy rating and USD 22 price target on the co., citing that the Hortonworks merger is “looking good so far” and meeting deadlines for integration. (Newswires)
  • PG&E (PCG) – The struggling utilities co. has extended its shareholder submission deadline for board member nominees from March 29th up until 17:00 PDT on April 1st as it continues talks with its shareholders. Elsewhere, WSJ reports that a Californian district judge has threatened to withdraw the co.’s ability to resume paying dividends if it has not taken appropriate measures to prevent fires. (Newswires/WSJ)
  • Teva (TEVA) – The pharma co. has received EU marketing authorisation for its migraine treatment, AJOVY 225mg. (Newswires)
  • Vale (VALE) – The Brazilian miner has had an additional USD 255mln of assets frozen, again to be used as potential compensation for the damages from its recent dam bust. (Newswires)

  • CELGENE (CELG) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT UBS
  • Coty (COTY) – JPMorgan has added the co. to its short idea list, citing little fundamental reason for the stock to maintain its current valuation. (Newswires)
  • Kellogg (K) – The packaged foods co. is close to an agreement to sell its Keebler, famous Amos and fruit snacks unit to the private Italian-based Ferrero for a value between USD 1bln-1.5bln.

 

1st April 2019

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL), Tesla (TSLA) – Tesla’s VP of Engineering, Michael Schwekutsch, has joined Apple’s Special Project Group, where its autonomous vehicle unit, Project Titan, is located, Schwekutsch is one of several Tesla engineers to join the group. (Electrek)
  • Boeing (BA) – Tensions have been escalating between US and Ethiopian authorities over the handling of data from Boeing’s 737 MAX Jet crash, where the US are accusing Ethiopia of having an “aloof” attitude and being slow to provide information. Elsewhere, Norway Air’s CEO is to hold talks with the co. over issues related to MAX jets, the airline has eighteen 737 MAX 8 jets and is scheduled to take delivery of more. (WSJ/Newswires)
  • Cisco (CSCO) – The tech co.’s CEO Chuck Robbins has said that those who doubted its subscription-based networking models have been wrong, where 65% of its software revenue has originated from subscriptions, with software and service expected to reach 30% of its total revenue over the next few years. (CRN)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The personal products conglomerate has disagreed with Indian regulators’ interim data on its baby powder products, which determines its baby shampoo contains “harmful ingredients”. (Newswires)
  • Merck (MRK) – The pharma giant’s cancer treatment KEYTRUDA, in combination with chemotherapy, has been approved in China for the treatment of lung cancer, conditional on data from the Phase 3 KEYNOTE-189 trial, which would make it the first anti-PD-1 therapy approved for more than one tumour type in the country. Elsewhere, Merck, alongside AstraZeneca (AZN), have been granted FDA Breakthrough Approval Designation for their rare genetics disease treatment in kids, selumetinib. (Newswires)
  • Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) – As the pharmacy introduces efforts to trial tobacco free stores, it has said it has no intentions to stop selling tobacco products completely, a hopeful sign for Altria Group (MO), British American Tobacco (BTI) and Philip Morris (PM). (WSJ)

S&P500

  • Casino/Resorts (LVS, MGM, WYNN, MLCO) – China’s Macau region reported gross casino-related revenue down by 0.4% in March YY to 25.84bln patacas. (Newswires)
  • Citigroup (C) – The bank’s consumer unit, as according to its annual proxy statement, is set to miss its 2020 financial targets, with its head, Stephen Bird, receiving the lowest score amongst his colleagues for financial performance. (FT)
  • Coty (COTY) – The cosmetics co. has announced the extension of the tender offer for 150mln shares by JAB at a price of USD 11.65 per share. Elsewhere, JPMorgan has added the co. to its short idea list, citing little fundamental reason for the stock to maintain its current valuation. (Newswires)
  • Discovery (DISCA) – The broadcaster has signed a “multi-million pound” partnership with the BBC, where Discovery will act as the global home for BBC’s factual series content, including the popular Planet Earth, Blue Planet and Life collection of titles, and provide bespoke development for BBC studios. The deal will see the breakup of broadcaster UKTV and create a new global on-demand video streaming service. (Newswires)
  • Kellogg (K) – The packaged foods co. is close to an agreement to sell its Keebler, famous Amos and fruit snacks unit to the private Italian-based Ferrero for a value between USD 1bln-1.5bln. (CNBC)
  • MasterCard (MA) – The credit card provider has had its price target raised to USD 267 from USD 221 at Deutsche Bank, with analyst Bryan Keane reiterating his Buy rating, citing “strong fundamentals” globally. (Newswires)
  • Southwest (LUV) – The airline has extended its grounding of Boeing’s (BA) 737 MAX jet from April 20th until and through May. Elsewhere, Southwest experienced some technical difficulties which cause delays to flights but has since been resolved. (Newswires)
  • V.F. Corp. (VFC) – The apparel retailer has filed its Form 10 registration statement for its previously announced separation of its Jeanswear unit into a separately traded public company, which will be named Kontoor Brands, containing the Wrangler, Lee and Rock & Republic brands, and the VF Outlet business. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s magazine gave positive mentions for AT&T (T), DowDuPont (DWDP), Dow Inc. (DOW), Amphenol (APH), AbbVie (ABBV), International Paper (IP), Prudential Financial (PRU), Broadcom (AVGO), and Best Buy (BBY). However, the publication was cautious on Apple (AAPL), citing its disappointing Special Event last Monday. (Barron’s)

NASDAQ

  • Activision Blizzard (ATVI) – The video-game developer has been added to Wedbush’s Best Ideas list, analyst Michael Pachter maintains his Outperform rating and USD 56 price target, citing potential for earnings beats for FY19. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The retail giant’s security chief for CEO Jeff Bezos has said that the Saudi government gained access to Bezos’ phone, after an investigation into the leaked text messages of Bezos’ affair in the National Enquirer publication, it is not yet known if the Saudi’s extracted the text messages. Elsewhere, the co. has had its price target raised to USD 2,085 from USD 1,975 at Oppenheimer, after analyst Jason Helfstein reassessed his AWS model. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media co.’s CEO Mark Zuckerberg has called for governments to ramp up their role for regulating the internet in four main areas: to protect society from harmful content; to ensure election integrity; to protect people’s privacy; and to ensure data portability. Elsewhere, BI reports that the co.s has accidentally deleted some old Facebook posts by Zuckerberg such as its historic Instagram acquisition, citing technical errors. (CNBC/BI)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – Researchers have determined that mass user data can be extracted from Tesla vehicles after a crash, where someone with the right aptitude can gain from vehicles sent to salvage. (CNBC)

OTHER NEWS

  • Cable ONE (CABO) – The telecoms co. is to acquire the private Fidelity Communications Co.’s data, voice and video assets for USD 526mln in cash. (Newswires)
  • Cloudera (CLDR) – After attending a data conference, BTIG analyst Edward Parker maintained his Buy rating and USD 22 price target on the co., citing that the Hortonworks merger is “looking good so far” and meeting deadlines for integration. (Newswires)
  • PG&E (PCG) – The struggling utilities co. has extended its shareholder submission deadline for board member nominees from March 29th up until 17:00 PDT on April 1st as it continues talks with its shareholders. Elsewhere, WSJ reports that a Californian district judge has threatened to withdraw the co.’s ability to resume paying dividends if it has not taken appropriate measures to prevent fires. (Newswires/WSJ)
  • Teva (TEVA) – The pharma co. has received EU marketing authorisation for its migraine treatment, AJOVY 225mg. (Newswires)
  • Vale (VALE) – The Brazilian miner has had an additional USD 255mln of assets frozen, again to be used as potential compensation for the damages from its recent dam bust. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 1st April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European indices are firmly in the green [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.8%] as the China fueled momentum rolls on from overnight
  • Dollar underperforms most G10 counterparts; excluding JPY which is subdued by the improvement in risk sentiment
  • Another busy day of Brexit ahead, amendment selection for today’s indicative votes by Speaker Bercow due around 14:30BST/08:30CDT & voting to commence around 20:00BST/14:00CDT
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Manufacturing PMIs, US Retail Sales, Business Inventories, Construction Spending, ISM Mfg, ECB’s de Guindos, BoC’s Poloz

 

ASIA  

Asian equity markets began the new quarter on the front-foot with momentum sustained from last Friday’s global rally in which the S&P 500 notched its best quarterly performance in nearly a decade and as the region also cheered encouraging Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) gained from the open in which Consumer Staples led the broad gains across Australia’s sectors after Woolworths completed the sale of its petrol business and announced to return funds through a AUD 1.7bln off-market buyback, while the Japanese benchmark shrugged off a weak Tankan survey and was among the best performers with risk appetite fuelled by favourable currency flows. Hang Seng (+1.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.6%) were uplifted by strong Chinese data in which the Official Manufacturing, Non-Manufacturing and Caixin Manufacturing PMIs all topped estimates with the official reading in expansionary territory for the first time since October. Furthermore, trade optimism and the inclusion of China’s onshore bonds in the Bloomberg Barclays Global Aggregate Index from today further added to the optimism with the mainland firmly extending on the over-3% gains seen on Friday and with the Hang Seng now in bull market territory. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid similar weakness in T-notes and as a rally across riskier assets dampened safe-haven demand, while the BoJ recently announced its purchase intentions for the month in which it kept all amounts unchanged.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7193 (Prev. 6.7335)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 50.5 vs. Exp. 49.5 (Prev. 49.2); First expansion since October. (Newswires) Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 54.8 vs. Exp. 54.5 (Prev. 54.3) Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 50.8 vs. Exp. 50.1 (Prev. 49.9)

Reports from Chinese press that suggested China-US trade talks have made 'new' progress. (Newswires)

Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Index (Q1) 12 vs. Exp. 14.0 (Prev. 19.0); 2 year low. (Newswires) Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Outlook (Q1) 8 vs. Exp. 12.0 (Prev. 15.0) Japanese Tankan Large All Industry Capex (Q1) 1.2% vs. Exp. -0.4% (Prev. 14.3%)

UK/EU   

*For reference, a Brexit analysis piece for today’s events is available in the form of a rolling post on the headline feed

Over the weekend there were comments from Conservative Party Deputy Chairman Cleverly that the party is not preparing for a snap general election as it wouldn’t solve anything and could cause an “unnecessary delay’’ to Brexit. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK Justice Secretary Gauke has suggested that PM May could have to “accept” UK staying in customs union and break a 2017 general election manifesto pledge. (Telegraph)

Sources confirm that those close to UK PM May will push for a new PM to be selected after the Conservative Party conference in September. (Guardian)

An EU Diplomat has stated the political declaration could be amended ‘very quickly’, and that it may ‘be expected’ that EU leaders would agree to a further Brexit delay to the May 22nd one if a House of Commons majority backed a deal revised on such lines. (FT) Following this, EU are closely watching today's indicative vote process, would welcome a softer Brexit, Brussels say the can amend the political declaration quickly if MP's unite around a softer Brexit, and that all Brexit forms require the WA to pass., BBC's Adler. (Twitter)

European Commission President Juncker stated that patience was running out with the UK, and the EU wants UK MP’s to reach an agreement over Brexit in the coming hours and days. (BBC)

Labour has not tabled a motion for today's indicative votes, implying their effort will be on trying to secure support for Kyle/Wilson, which calls for a confirmatory referendum [Amednment E]., ITV's Peston. While, UK's SNP could support Nick Boles Common Market 2.0 proposal [D] today in indicative votes (if selected), according to BBC's Eardley. Separately, Up to 26 UK ministers are considering voting for Brexit option [C] for a customs union; assuming they get a free vote, according to Times' Deputy Political Editor Coates. (Twitter)

UK Treasury Minister Truss states that people are coming on board with UK PM May's plan, following it losing by a smaller amount in parliament last Friday. (Newswires)

Cabinet has not been told yet whether they will be expected to abstain on all choices tonight in indicative votes process, as according to sources cited by Sky's Cohen. (Twitter)

ECB’s Knot (hawk) commented that the ECB would need a clear monetary-policy reason to consider acting to mitigate the effects of negative interest rates on banks and expressed doubts regarding tiered deposit rates as a best solution for banks’ excess liquidity, while he also suggested it was clear that even policy normalization interest rates would be below pre-crisis levels. (Newswires)

ECB's Lautenschlaeger states that the rise of inflation is slower than what was expected. (Newswires)

 

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 55.1 vs. Exp. 51.0 (Prev. 52.0)

- Stocks of inputs & finished goods rise at record rates

- Trends in output, new orders & employment strengthen

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Mar) 47.5 vs. Exp. 47.6 (Prev. 47.6)

German Markit/BME Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 44.1 vs. Exp. 44.7 (Prev. 44.7)

- French Markit Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 49.7 vs. Exp. 49.8 (Prev. 49.8)

- Spanish Manufacturing PMI Mar 50.9 vs. Exp. 49.6 (Prev. 49.9)

- Italian Markit/IHS Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 47.4 vs. Exp. 47.4 (Prev. 47.7)

EU HICP Flash YY Mar 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.5%)

EQUITIES

A stellar start to the week for European stocks [Eurostoxx 50 +0.7%] following an inspiring performance in Asia where mainland China advanced in excess of 2% on the back of optimistic China manufacturing PMIs. Broad-based gains are being seen across major European indices, although Germany’s DAX (+1.5%) modestly outperforms peers, driven forward by the likes of auto names [Daimler +3.5%, Volkswagen +2.6% and BMW +1.8%] after Chinese PMIs topped estimates. Furthermore, the release also bolstered other China exposed sectors, i.e. luxury names, with Swatch (+1.4%), Richemont (+0.8%), LMVH (+1.0%) all performing well in their respective bourses. Sectors are also showing broad-based positivity, although utilities are underperforming as investors move away from defensive stocks. In terms of notable movers, WPP (+3.2%) rests at the top of the FTSE after a Deutsche Bank upgrade, whilst easyJet (-7.9%) shares declined after company CEO warned of a cautious H2 outlook as he expects softer yields from UK and European tickets.

FX

AUD/NZD/GBP/NOK/SEK - All beneficiaries of forecast-beating PMIs, albeit indirectly in the case of the Antipodean Dollars, as encouraging Chinese surveys overnight lifted broad risk sentiment and the Aussie and Kiwi accordingly. Meanwhile, a significantly better than expected UK headline print was mainly boosted by further pre-Brexit stock-piling, although output, new orders and jobs sub-components also improved and activity in both Scandi manufacturing sectors expanded at a faster pace. Hence, Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are both looking firmer above big figure levels at 0.7100 and 0.6800 respectively, with the former also probing above its 50 DMA (0.7119), while Cable extended its rebound from last week’s lows and back over 1.3000 to circa 1.3100, breaching its 55 DMA (1.3075) on the way. However, the latest round of IVs present more risk and uncertainty for the Pound with up to 8 amendments up for selection around 2.30 pm before debates and voting tonight – for a more detailed schedule and analysis see our headline feed. Elsewhere, Eur/Nok is back down below 9.6500 and Eur/Sek sub-10.4000 to test multi technical support levels including the 30 DMA (10.3844), 200 DMA (10.3812) and the bottom of a chart cloud (10.3785). Back down under, and the Aud will be looking for independent impetus via the RBA tomorrow with options pricing a 35 pip break-even for the event – full preview also available via the headline feed.

EUR/CHF - Also firmer vs the Usd as the DXY retreats towards 97.000 again, but capped around 1.1250 and 0.9935 respectively in wake of relatively downbeat PMIs and Swiss retail sales.

CAD/JPY - The G10 laggards, as the Loonie meanders between 1.3340-30 vs its US counterpart and the Jpy pivots 111.00 amidst the aforementioned general revival in risk appetite post-Chinese PMIs, and with the headline pair also underpinned by a downbeat Japanese Tankan report. However, 111.20 is holding (just) and represents a 61.8% Fib retracement of the 112.13-109.70 downmove.

EM - Contrasting fortunes for the Lira and Rand, as weekend municipal elections in Turkey saw some key losses for the ruling AK Party to main opposition CHP, but not enough to threaten President Erdogan’s overall majority and result in regime change. Usd/Try has been up to 5.7000+ in response vs Usd/Zar that has been as low as 14.2225 after Moody’s delayed its latest credit review of SA and any potential cut in the rating and/or outlook, for the time being at least.

Turkey opposition party claimed victory in Istanbul and Ankara, while the ruling AK Party also initially claimed to have won in Istanbul following local elections over the weekend which was seen as a referendum on President Erdogan. However. President Erdogan later commented that although the Mayorship may have been lost in Istanbul, they won in many of its municipalities. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Stock-piling certainly boosted the UK manufacturing PMI, but stock-taking appears to have contributed to the demise of Gilts and Bunds in recent trade following fleeting and mixed recoveries ahead of the Markit/CIPS release (which for the record was on time unlike the premature Eurozone surveys). The 10 year UK benchmark retested bids ahead of 129.00 again, having peered 1 tick above par at 129.38, while its Eurex equivalent has actually fallen to a fresh session low at 165.68 (-66 ticks) amidst extended gains in the Dax other EU bourses. Elsewhere, US Treasuries remain closer to overnight lows with the curve steeper again ahead of top-tier data in the form of retail sales, manufacturing PMI/ISM business inventories and construction spending.

COMMODITIES

The upbeat sentiment emanating from the optimistic China metrics overnight has supported sentiment alongside the demand outlook for the energy complex. Brent futures are marching with gains of around USD 1.0/bbl while WTI futures advance over USD 0.50/bbl. Brent oil has reached levels last seen in November, and from a technical front, the 200 DMA for Brent resides around USD 69.68/bbl and around USD 61.50/bbl for WTI. Furthermore, BAML expects Brent to average USD 74/bbl in Q2 2019, and USD 70/bbl in 2019. Meanwhile, the bank sees WTI averaging USD 56/bbl in 2019 and USD 60/bbl in 2020. Elsewhere, the latest CFTC data shows that speculative net long NYMEX WTI by almost 26k lots over last week, with a bulk of the buying coming from fresh longs. Of note, this month sees the EIA short-term energy outlook release on the 9th, OPEC monthly report on the 10th and IAE oil market report the day after. It is also worth noting that traders will be keeping an eye on trade developments as US is to host a Chinese trade delegation on the 3rd.

Over in the metals complex, gold prices succumb to the positive risk tone as the yellow metal remains below the USD 1300/oz, albeit off lows. Meanwhile, the aforementioned China data bolstered copper prices to levels just shy of USD 3.00/lb, to levels last seen in June 2018. Elsewhere, iron ore prices have been supported by the Caixin-beat alongside a force majeure by Rio Tinto which will result in a loss of around 14mln tonnes of production this year. As such, Goldman Sachs raised iron ore price forecasts with 3-month estimate at USD 85/ton (Prev. USD 80), 6-month estimate at USD 80/ton (Prev. USD 75/ton) and 1-year estimate at USD 70/ton (Prev. USD 65).

The Omani oil minister says that he sees prices staying in a USD 65-75 range until year-end. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto sees Pilbara iron ore shipments to be at lower end of 338mln-350mln tons and expects impact of disruption from cyclone will result in loss of around 14mln tonnes of production this year. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs raised iron ore price forecasts with 3-month estimate at USD 85/ton (Prev. USD 80), 6-month estimate at USD 80/ton (Prev. USD 75/ton) and 1-year estimate at USD 70/ton (Prev. USD 65). (Newswires)

Bank of America see Brent averaging USD 74/bbl in Q2 2019, USD 70/bbl in 2019 and USD 65/bbl in 2020; see WTI averaging USD 56/bbl in 2019 and USD 60/bbl in 2020. (Newswires)

Oil exports from the Russian port of Tuapse are forecast at 1.429mln tons in April vs. 0.824mln tons scheduled in March, according to traders. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk EU Mid Session: China PMIs fuel investors’ risk appetite ahead of Brexit bedlam - 1st April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

A stellar start to the week for European stocks [Eurostoxx 50 +1.0%] following an inspiring performance in Asia where mainland China advanced in excess of 2% on the back of optimistic China manufacturing PMIs. Broad-based gains are being seen across major European indices, although Germany’s DAX (+1.5%) modestly outperforms peers, driven forward by the likes of auto names [Daimler +3.4%, Volkswagen +3.4% and BMW +2.4%] after Chinese PMIs topped estimates. Furthermore, the release also bolstered other China exposed sectors, i.e. luxury names, with Swatch (+2.5%), Richemont (+2.2%), LMVH (+1.5%) all performing well in their respective bourses. Sectors are also showing broad-based positivity, although utilities are underperforming as investors move away from defensive stocks. In terms of notable movers, WPP (+3.8%) rests at the top of the FTSE after a Deutsche Bank upgrade, whilst easyJet (-7.8%) shares declined after company CEO warned of a cautious H2 outlook as he expects softer yields from UK and European tickets. Elsewhere, Panalpina (+14.6%) shares surged higher after the company reached an agreement for a merger with DSV (-1.0%) which could be dubbed “DSV Panalpina”.

FX

AUD/NZD/GBP/NOK/SEK - All beneficiaries of forecast-beating PMIs, albeit indirectly in the case of the Antipodean Dollars, as encouraging Chinese surveys overnight lifted broad risk sentiment and the Aussie and Kiwi accordingly. Meanwhile, a significantly better than expected UK headline print was mainly boosted by further pre-Brexit stock-piling, although output, new orders and jobs sub-components also improved and activity in both Scandi manufacturing sectors expanded at a faster pace. Hence, Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are both looking firmer above big figure levels at 0.7100 and 0.6800 respectively, with the former also probing above its 50 DMA (0.7119), while Cable extended its rebound from last week’s lows and back over 1.3000 to just shy of 1.3100, breaching its 55 DMA (1.3075) on the way. However, the latest round of IVs present more risk and uncertainty for the Pound with up to 8 amendments up for selection around 2.30 pm before debates and voting tonight – for a more detailed schedule and analysis see our headline feed. Elsewhere, Eur/Nok is back down below 9.6500 and Eur/Sek sub-10.4000 to test multi technical support levels including the 30 DMA (10.3844), 200 DMA (10.3812) and the bottom of a chart cloud (10.3785). subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures on the defensive pre-UK Manufacturing PMI and IVs
content: UK debt and STIR contracts are paring some losses ahead of the March manufacturing survey that may carry downside risks against consensus given ongoing Brexit uncertainty and weaker than forecast Eurozone surveys overall, while the next set of Parliamentary votes also warrant caution as snap election talk ratchets up a notch along with the prospect of PM May bringing back her deal for a 4th time. However, Gilts and the 3 month strip are also respecting a strong start to the new week, month and quarter in EU stocks on the back of encouraging Chinese PMIs overnight, with the 10 year bond ranging from 129.24-128.98 vs last Friday’s 129.37 settlement and Short Sterling straddling parity within +0.5 to -1.5 tick parameters.

subject: Bunds: bowing to better than expected PMIs
content: The 10 year German benchmark has been on the back foot and extending loss from an initial markdown to 166.21 vs last Friday’s 166.34 close, acknowledging a similar downturn in US Treasuries on the back of heightened risk appetite in wake of China’s better than forecast PMIs overnight, and with a further lurch towards the 165.90 low coming after Spain’s manufacturing PMI also beat consensus and returned to the right side of the 50.0 divide. Note, however, the German, French and pan Eurozone prelim surveys were very disappointing and it would take considerable upward revisions to restore the headline readings from contractionary territory. Also ahead, Eurozone flash CPI and a speech by ECB’s de Guindos.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Sanofi (SAN FP) – Co. guides Q1 favourable currency impact on revenue of around 2% and around 1.5-2.0% on EPS. (Newswires)

UK Telecom Names – As of Monday, customers will automatically receive compensation from broadband and landline providers when services do not work; BT (BT/A LN), Sky, TalkTalk, Virgin Media & Zen have signed up to the non-compulsory scheme from Ofcom. (BBC)

Royal Mail (RMG LN) – UK Shadow Chancellor McDonnel has stated that a new ‘Post Bank’ would protect community banking, with the proposal to run the bank through the Co’s Post Office network could create up to 3600 branches. (BBC)

Superdry (SDRY LN) – Investec Asset Management & Schroders have backed the Co’s co-founder’s fight to be reinstated as a director of the Co. (Sky)

easyJet (EZJ LN) – Co. sees increasing softness in ticket yields in the UK and across Europe, hence H2 outlook is now more cautious. H1 underlying revenue is expected to be positive and in-line. Total H1 revenue is expected to grow by around 7.3%. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – Spiegel reports that the Co. may have paid bribes in the Egyptair Deals during 2003-2008. (Spiegel)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) - Co’s s Selumetinib gets breakthrough therapy designation for patients with NF1 Plexiform Neurofibromas. (Newswires)

IAG (IAG LN) – British Airways employee unions are urging their members to reject the airlines pay proposal, and are to start industrial action preparations. (Newswires)

Nokia (NOKIA FH) – Daimler (DAI GY) has complained to EU antitrust regulator about Co,’s patents essential to communication.

Novartis (NOVN SW) - Teva has dropped Copaxone patent case against the Co. (Newswires) 

Osram Licht (OSR GY) – Co. CEO reports good progress in regards in talks with Bain and Carlyle group. (Newswire)

Delivery Hero (DHER GY) – Takeaway.com listing and admission of 5.733mln ordinary shares, with a nominal value of EUR 0.04 each; consideration shares will be issued to the Co. in connection with the acquisition. (Newswires)

Subsea 7 (SUBC NO) – Co. have been awarded 2 contracts from Saudi Aramco, relating to conventional projects in shallow water offshore Saudi Arabia, due to begin in 2020. (Newswires)

Bankia (BKIA SM) – Co. have closed agreement with Mapfre for the restructuring progress of Bancaassurance business, operations price totals EUR 110.3mln. Transactions closing implies the completion of the restructuring process. (Newswires)

WPP (WPP LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT DEUTSCHE BANK

KINGFISHER (KGF LN) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

CAIXA BANK (CABK SM) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM SELL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

1st April 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the new quarter on the front-foot with momentum sustained from last Friday’s global rally in which the S&P 500 notched its best quarterly performance in nearly a decade and as the region also cheered encouraging Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) gained from the open in which Consumer Staples led the broad gains across Australia’s sectors after Woolworths completed the sale of its petrol business and announced to return funds through a AUD 1.7bln off-market buyback, while the Japanese benchmark shrugged off a weak Tankan survey and was among the best performers with risk appetite fuelled by favourable currency flows. Hang Seng (+1.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.3%) were uplifted by strong Chinese data in which the Official Manufacturing, Non-Manufacturing and Caixin Manufacturing PMIs all topped estimates with the official reading in expansionary territory for the first time since October.  Furthermore, trade optimism and the inclusion of China’s onshore bonds in the Bloomberg Barclays Global Aggregate Index from today further added to the optimism with the mainland firmly extending on the over-3% gains seen on Friday and with the Hang Seng now in bull market territory.

FTSE

Inmarsat (ISAT LN) – Co.’s deal to acquire Apax (APAX LN) and Warbug Pincus will be reviewed by the Committee of Foreign Interments in the US (CFIUS) which derailed Broadcom’s hostile offer for Qualcomm last year amid concerns of about Chinese involvement. (Telegraph)

British Land (BLND LN) – Co. has sold its entire portfolio of pubs for GBP 130mln as the Co. continues to pursue larger developments. Co, agreed to hand over 45 pubs, occupied by Greene King’s (GKN LN) Spirit Pub Company to investor Aprirose. (Telegraph)

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) - Co. sees Pilbara iron ore shipments to be at lower end of 338mln-350mln tons and expects impact of disruption from cyclone will result in loss of around 14mln tonnes of production this year. (Newswires)

BT (BT/A LN) – CEO is reportedly looking at the closure of 20/50 offices in the UK over the next 3-5 years. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co. have successfully placed around 44.4mln shares at GBP 60.50 a shares; which has raised around GBP 2.7bln. (Newswires)

Gambling Names – The maximum stake that can be placed on fixed odds betting terminal will be cut to GBP 2 from GBP 100 on Monday. Industry figures have stated this will lead to the closure of up to 1/3 of high street betting shops. (FT/BBC)

Babcock (BAB LN) – Ruth Cairnie, a former Shell (RDSA LN) executive, has become the frontrunner to become the Co’s first woman chair. The announcement may occur within the next 10 days. (FT)

HSBC (HSBA LN) – Three Co. directors have sold a total of GBP 1.7mln in shares. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

ROYAL MAIL (RMG LN) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT BERENBERG

SMITHS GROUP (SMIN LN) REITERATED OUTPERFORM AT RBC

ANTOFAGASTA (ANTO LN) DOWNGRADED TO DOWNGRADE FROM HOLD AT PEEL HUNT

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Executive Hoops, has stated that the Commerzbank (CBK GY) deal will not impact revenue and that clients will not leave following the merger. (FT)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Co’s “Seat” brand will begin manufacturing 6 hybrid & fully-electric models from next year; and are to lead the development of a small electric vehicle platform for use by the Co’s entire group. Targeting the production of a battery-run vehicle which is under EUR 20k.  (FT)

BROKER MOVES

BAYER (BAYN GY) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT DEUTSCHE BANK

CAC

ORANGE (ORA FP) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

BT (BT/A LN)/ Vodafone (VOD LN)/Telefonica (TEF SM) – Co’s are nearing a deal to tackle rural coverage amid rising threat of new regulations after research from Ofcom found that over a fifth of the country cannot make a voice call on BT, O2, Three and Vodafone. (Telegraph)

Saipem (SPM IM) – Co. have reportedly entered into talks to exit the drilling business; according to sources. (Newswires)

Peugeot (UG FP)/Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) – Co.’s are looking into a partnership to share investments to manufacture vehicles in Europe, according to sources. (Newswires) 

DSV (DSV DC) – Co. and Panalpina have reached an agreement regarding a transaction with an enterprise value of CHF 4.6bln. Following its completion, DSV proposed a name change to “DSV Panalpina”. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

POSTNL (PNL NA) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG

BBVA (BBVA SM) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT DEUTSCHE BANK

PRYSMIAN (PRY IM) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT GOLDMAN SACHS

UNICREDIT (UCG IM) ADDED TO CONVICTION LIST AT GOLDMAN SACHS

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – Co. is to acquire IFM Therapeutics for a total of USD 1.575bln (USD 310mln upfront, with up to USD 1.265bln in milestones), in an attempt to develop first-in-class portfolio targeting innate immune system. (Newswires)

SCANDINAVIA

Swedbank (SWEDA SS) – Sweden’s chief prosecutor for financial matters has accused the Co. of blocking police when they raided their headquarters as part of a fraud investigation; while the Co’s lawyers have called the comments ‘incomprehensible’ (FT)
